Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Causes and consequences of evolvability in natural and lab-evolved bacterial populations
Award.AbstractNarration:
Long-term success will often require the ability to adapt to changing conditions. In biological populations the capacity to do this, termed evolvability, can play a crucial role in determining evolutionary winners and losers. Nevertheless, systematic study of evolvability is difficult. Its underlying mechanisms, how it can be selected, and how it influences evolutionary outcomes, remain poorly understood. This project will address these questions using lab-evolved and natural isolates of a model bacterium, Escherichia coli. The ability to follow population evolution in real time, and to compete a population's past (stored as a frozen, but revivable sample) against its future will be used to directly examine the effect and consequences of differences in evolvability. Sequencing of bacterial genomes will allow the genetic basis of observed differences to be determined.

Findings of experiments that are explicitly designed to examine evolvability will represent a significant basic contribution to the field of evolutionary biology, not least in contributing to a goal of being able to make general predictions about evolutionary responses. An understanding of the genetic and physiological basis of evolvability will be relevant to fields such as vaccine and antibiotic design (where evolvability is something to be countered) and biotechnology (where evolvability will often be something to be exploited). The project will make significant and novel contributions to training of undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The mutations that underlie adaptation interact so that their combined effect can differ from an expectation based on their individual effects. Theoretical models predict that these deviations, known as epistasis, can have a major impact on evolutionary outcomes, effecting the rate and repeatability of adaptation. We tested these predictions in experiments examining evolutionary dynamics and mutational effects in laboratory evolved populations of Escherichia coli bacteria. The use of laboratory evolved populations allows us to control processes that would otherwise complicate the interpretation of evolutionary outcomes. We isolated a set of strains that comprise steps in the early part of the evolutionary trajectory of one evolved population and started new replicate populations from each of these steps to determine how the range and repeatability of evolutionary outcomes changed during adaptation. We found that the potential for strains to continue to improve in the selective environment declined over time, and that this effect was due to a reduction in the benefit conferred by available beneficial mutations. By comparing the effect of mutations that did occur in a series of different strains, we determined that the decline in benefit was due to the build up of interactions that cause mutations to be less beneficial when added to strains that already have high fitness. This interaction creates a pattern of diminishing returns—the fitter a strain is, the harder it is to improve further. By introducing the same beneficial mutations into a set of E. coli isolated from natural environments we demonstrated that this phenomenon can also explain a significant portion of the effect of mutations moved between divergent strains. This finding is significant because DNA transfer between strains is now recognized as a major contributor to bacterial evolution. In other experiments we identified and characterized other patterns of interactions between mutations that underlie a switch point at which replicate populations follow mutually exclusive evolutionary paths and that cause a history of selection in one environment to increase a populations ability to adapt to a second environment. We showed that this effect of history depended on the capacitor like accumulation of beneficial mutations that were masked by a single antagonistically acting mutation. When this antagonistic mutation was selected against, the effects of the accumulated mutations was revealed resulting in a sharp increase in fitness. Our findings extend understanding of the effect of mutation interactions in influencing evolutionary outcomes, especially building on a role for diminishing returns interactions in underlying a predictable pattern of fitness change.
